change.subject: Part 1
change.quote: This Act provides for a new regulatory framework which has the general purpose of making the use of internet services regulated by this Act safer for individuals in the United Kingdom.
To achieve that purpose, this Act (among other things)—

(a) imposes duties which, in broad terms, require providers of services regulated by this Act to identify, mitigate and manage the risks of harm (including risks which particularly affect individuals with a certain characteristic) from—
(i) illegal content and activity, and
(ii) content and activity that is harmful to children, and
(b) confers new functions and powers on the regulator, OFCOM.
change.summary: The Act introduces a new regulatory framework to make internet services safer in the UK. It imposes duties on providers to identify and manage risks of harm from illegal content and content harmful to children. It also grants new functions and powers to the regulator, OFCOM.

change.subject: Part 2
change.quote: Part 2 contains key definitions, including the definition of a user-to-user service, a search service, a Part 3 service and a regulated service.
change.summary: Part 2 of the Act provides key definitions, including those for user-to-user service, search service, Part 3 service, and regulated service.

change.subject: Part 3
change.quote: Part 3 imposes duties of care on providers of user-to-user services and search services and requires OFCOM to issue codes of practice about those duties.
change.summary: Part 3 of the Act imposes duties of care on providers of user-to-user services and search services. It also requires OFCOM to issue codes of practice regarding these duties.

change.subject: Part 4
change.quote: Part 4 imposes further duties on providers of user-to-user services and search services.
change.summary: Part 4 of the Act imposes additional duties on providers of user-to-user services and search services.

change.subject: Part 5
change.quote: Part 5 imposes duties on providers of internet services (including user-to-user services and search services) that publish certain pornographic content.
change.summary: Part 5 of the Act imposes duties on providers of internet services, including user-to-user services and search services, that publish specific pornographic content.

change.subject: Part 6
change.quote: Part 6, which imposes requirements to pay fees to OFCOM, applies to providers of internet services to which the duties in Part 3, 4 or 5 apply (“regulated services”).
change.summary: Part 6 of the Act requires providers of internet services, to which the duties in Part 3, 4, or 5 apply, to pay fees to OFCOM. These services are referred to as "regulated services".

change.subject: Part 7
change.quote: Part 7 is about OFCOM’s powers and duties in relation to regulated services (including powers to obtain information and enforcement powers).
change.summary: Part 7 of the Act outlines OFCOM's powers and duties regarding regulated services, including the power to obtain information and enforcement powers.

change.subject: Part 8
change.quote: Part 8 is about appeals and complaints relating to regulated services.
change.summary: Part 8 of the Act addresses appeals and complaints related to regulated services.

change.subject: Part 9
change.quote: Part 9 is about the Secretary of State’s functions in relation to regulated services.
change.summary: Part 9 of the Act outlines the functions of the Secretary of State regarding regulated services.

change.subject: Part 10
change.quote: Part 10 contains communications offences.
change.summary: Part 10 of the Act includes provisions for communications offences.

change.subject: Part 11
change.quote: Parts 11 and 12 contain supplementary provisions including an index of terms defined in this Act (see section 238).
change.summary: Parts 11 and 12 of the Act contain supplementary provisions, including an index of terms defined in the Act.

change.subject: subsection (2)
change.quote: "For the purposes of subsection (1)— (a) it does not matter if content is actually shared with another user or users as long as a service has a functionality that allows such sharing; (b) it does not matter what proportion of content on a service is content described in that subsection."
change.summary: The proposed change clarifies that it does not matter if content is actually shared with other users, as long as the service has the functionality to allow sharing. It also states that the proportion of content on a service that falls under the described subsection does not matter.

change.subject: subsection (4)
change.quote: "(4) In this Act “search service” means an internet service that is, or includes, a search engine (see section 230)."
change.summary: The proposed change defines "search service" as an internet service that is, or includes, a search engine.

change.subject: subsection (5)
change.quote: "(5) Subsections (6) and (7) have effect to determine whether an internet service that— (a) is of a kind described in subsection (1), and (b) includes a search engine, is a user-to-user service or a search service for the purposes of this Act."
change.summary: The proposed change states that subsections (6) and (7) will determine whether an internet service that falls under the described criteria is classified as a user-to-user service or a search service for the purposes of the Act.

change.subject: subsection (6)
change.quote: "(6) It is a search service if the only content described in subsection (1) that is enabled by the service is content of any of the following kinds— (a) content mentioned in paragraph 1, 2 or 3 of Schedule 1 (emails, SMS and MMS messages, one-to-one live aural communications) and related identifying content; (b) content arising in connection with any of the activities described in paragraph 4(1) of Schedule 1 (comments etc on provider content); (c) content present on a part of the service in relation to which the conditions in paragraph 7(2) of Schedule 1 are met (internal business service conditions)."
change.summary: The proposed change defines that a service is classified as a search service if the only content enabled by the service falls under the described categories in Schedule 1.

change.subject: subsection (7)
change.quote: "(7) Otherwise, it is a user-to-user service."
change.summary: The proposed change states that if the service does not meet the criteria described in subsection (6), it is classified as a user-to-user service.

change.subject: subsection (2)
change.quote: "(2) A user-to-user service is a “regulated user-to-user service”, and a search service is a “regulated search service”, if the service— (a) has links with the United Kingdom (see subsections (5) and (6)), and (b) is not— (i) a service of a description that is exempt as provided for by Schedule 1, or (ii) a service of a kind described in Schedule 2 (services combining user-generated content or search content not regulated by this Act with pornographic content that is regulated)."
change.summary: The proposed change defines that a user-to-user service is classified as a regulated user-to-user service, and a search service is classified as a regulated search service if the service has links with the United Kingdom and does not fall under the exemptions provided in Schedule 1 or the services described in Schedule 2.

change.subject: subsection (5)
change.quote: "(5) For the purposes of subsection (2), a user-to-user service or a search service “has links with the United Kingdom” if— (a) the service has a significant number of United Kingdom users, or (b) United Kingdom users form one of the target markets for the service (or the only target market)."
change.summary: The proposed change defines that a user-to-user service or a search service is considered to have links with the United Kingdom if it has a significant number of United Kingdom users or if United Kingdom users form one of the target markets for the service.

change.subject: subsection (6)
change.quote: "(6) For the purposes of subsection (2), a user-to-user service or a search service also “has links with the United Kingdom” if— (a) the service is capable of being used in the United Kingdom by individuals, and (b) there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is a material risk of significant harm to individuals in the United Kingdom presented by— (i) in the case of a user-to-user service, user-generated content present on the service or (if the service includes a search engine) search content of the service; (ii) in the case of a search service, search content of the service."
change.summary: The proposed change states that a user-to-user service or a search service is considered to have links with the United Kingdom if it is capable of being used in the United Kingdom by individuals and if there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is a material risk of significant harm to individuals in the United Kingdom presented by the user-generated content or search content of the service.

change.subject: subsection (7)
change.quote: "(7) A regulated user-to-user service that includes a public search engine is referred to in this Act as a “combined service”. “Public search engine” means a search engine other than one in relation to which the conditions in paragraph 7(2) of Schedule 1 (internal business service conditions) are met."
change.summary: The proposed change defines a regulated user-to-user service that includes a public search engine as a "combined service." It also defines a "public search engine" as a search engine that does not meet the conditions described in paragraph 7(2) of Schedule 1.

change.subject: subsection (8)
change.quote: "(8) In this section— “search content” has the same meaning as in Part 3 (see section 57); “user-generated content” has the meaning given by section 55 (see subsections (3) and (4) of that section)."
change.summary: The proposed change defines "search content" and "user-generated content" for the purposes of this section.

change.subject: subsection (1)
change.quote: "(1) This Act does not apply in relation to a part of a Part 3 service if the conditions in paragraph 7(2) of Schedule 1 (internal business service conditions) are met in relation to that part."
change.summary: The proposed change states that this Act does not apply to a part of a Part 3 service if the conditions described in paragraph 7(2) of Schedule 1 (internal business service conditions) are met for that part.

change.subject: subsection (2)
change.quote: "(2) This Act does not apply in relation to a part of a regulated search service if— (a) the only user-generated content enabled by that part of the service is content of any of the following kinds— (i) content mentioned in paragraph 1, 2 or 3 of Schedule 1 (emails, SMS and MMS messages, one-to-one live aural communications) and related identifying content; (ii) content arising in connection with any of the activities described in paragraph 4(1) of Schedule 1 (comments etc on provider content); and (b) no regulated provider pornographic content is published or displayed on that part of the service."
change.summary: The proposed change states that this Act does not apply to a part of a regulated search service if the only user-generated content enabled by that part of the service falls under the described categories in Schedule 1 and if no regulated provider pornographic content is published or displayed on that part of the service.

change.subject: subsection (3)
change.quote: "(3) In this section— “regulated provider pornographic content” and “published or displayed” have the same meaning as in Part 5 (see section 80); “user-generated content” has the meaning given by section 55 (see subsections (3) and (4) of that section)."
change.summary: The proposed change defines "regulated provider pornographic content," "published or displayed," and "user-generated content" for the purposes of this section.

change.subject: Chapter 1
change.quote: "PART 3 PROVIDERS OF REGULATED USER-TO-USER SERVICES AND REGULATED SEARCH SERVICES: DUTIES OF CARE CHAPTER 1 INTRODUCTION"
change.summary: The proposed change introduces Chapter 1 of Part 3, which provides an introduction to the duties of care for providers of regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services.

change.subject: Chapter 2
change.quote: "CHAPTER 2 PROVIDERS OF USER-TO-USER SERVICES: DUTIES OF CARE User-to-user services: which duties apply, and scope of duties"
change.summary: The proposed change introduces Chapter 2 of Part 3, which outlines the duties of care for providers of user-to-user services and specifies which duties apply and the scope of those duties.

change.subject: subsection (1)
change.quote: "(1) This Part imposes duties of care on providers of regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services and requires OFCOM to issue codes of practice relating to some of those duties."
change.summary: The proposed change states that this Part imposes duties of care on providers of regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services and requires OFCOM to issue codes of practice related to some of those duties.

change.subject: Section 6
change.quote: (6) A “children’s risk assessment” of a service of a particular kind means an assessment of the following matters, taking into account the risk profile that relates to services of that kind— (a) the user base, including the number of users who are children in different age groups; (b) the level of risk of children who are users of the service encountering the following by means of the service— (i) each kind of primary priority content that is harmful to children (with each kind separately assessed), (ii) each kind of priority content that is harmful to children (with each kind separately assessed), (iii) non-designated content that is harmful to children, and (iv) features, functionalities or behaviours (including those enabled or created by the design or operation of the service) that are harmful to children, giving separate consideration to children in different age groups, and taking into account (in particular) algorithms used by the service and how easily, quickly and widely content may be disseminated by means of the service; (c) the level of risk of harm to children presented by different kinds of content that is harmful to children, giving separate consideration to children in different age groups; (d) the level of risk of harm to children presented by content that is harmful to children which particularly affects individuals with a certain characteristic or members of a certain group; (e) the level of risk of functionalities of the service facilitating the presence or dissemination of content that is harmful to children, identifying and assessing those functionalities that present higher levels of risk, including functionalities— (i) enabling adults to search for other users of the service (including children), and (ii) enabling adults to contact other users (including children) by means of the service; (f) the different ways in which the service is used, and the impact of such use on the level of risk of harm that might be suffered by children; (g) the nature, and severity, of the harm that might be suffered by children from the matters identified in accordance with paragraphs (b) to (f), giving separate consideration to children in different age groups; (h) how the design and operation of the service (including the business model, governance, use of proactive technology, measures to promote users’ media literacy and safe use of the service, and other systems and processes) may reduce or increase the risks identified.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces the concept of a "children's risk assessment" for internet services. This assessment would evaluate various factors related to the risk of harm to children, including the user base, the types of harmful content, the functionalities of the service, and the design and operation of the service. The assessment would consider different age groups of children and the potential harm they may face. It would also take into account the use of algorithms and the ease of content dissemination. The purpose of this assessment is to identify and mitigate risks to children using the service.

change.subject: Section 12
change.quote: (2) A duty, in relation to a service, to take or use proportionate measures relating to the design or operation of the service to effectively— (a) mitigate and manage the risks of harm to children in different age groups, as identified in the most recent children’s risk assessment of the service (see section 11(6)(g)), (b) mitigate the impact of harm to children in different age groups presented by content that is harmful to children present on the service, and (c) mitigate the impact of harm to children in different age groups presented by features, functionalities or behaviours enabled or created by the design or operation of the service.
change.summary: This proposed change introduces a duty for service providers to take proportionate measures to mitigate and manage the risks of harm to children. These measures should be based on the most recent children's risk assessment of the service and should address the impact of harmful content and harmful features, functionalities, or behaviors enabled by the service's design or operation.

change.subject: Section 15
change.quote: (2) A duty to include in a service, to the extent that it is proportionate to do so, features which adult users may use or apply if they wish to increase their control over content to which this subsection applies. (3) The features referred to in subsection (2) are those which, if used or applied by a user, result in the use by the service of systems or processes designed to effectively— (a) reduce the likelihood of the user encountering content to which subsection (2) applies present on the service, or (b) alert the user to content present on the service that is a particular kind of content to which subsection (2) applies.
change.summary: This proposed change introduces a duty for service providers to include features in their services that allow adult users to increase their control over certain types of content. These features should be designed to reduce the likelihood of encountering such content or to alert users to its presence. The inclusion of these features aims to empower adult users and give them more control over their online experience.

change.subject: Section 17
change.quote: (2) A duty to operate a service using proportionate systems and processes designed to ensure that the importance of the free expression of content of democratic importance is taken into account when making decisions about— (a) how to treat such content (especially decisions about whether to take it down or restrict users’ access to it), and (b) whether to take action against a user generating, uploading or sharing such content. (3) A duty to ensure that the systems and processes mentioned in subsection (2) apply in the same way to a wide diversity of political opinion. (4) A duty to include provisions in the terms of service specifying the policies and processes that are designed to take account of the principle mentioned in subsection (2), including, in particular, how that principle is applied to decisions mentioned in that subsection.
change.summary: This proposed change introduces a duty for service providers to consider the importance of free expression of content of democratic importance when making decisions about how to treat such content and whether to take action against users generating, uploading, or sharing such content. The systems and processes used by the service should ensure that this duty applies equally to a wide diversity of political opinion. The terms of service should include provisions specifying the policies and processes designed to uphold this principle.

change.subject: Section 5(a)
change.quote: (a) the provisions of the terms of service referred to in subsection (4) are clear and accessible, and
(b) those provisions are applied consistently.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty for internet service providers to ensure that the provisions of their terms of service are clear, accessible, and applied consistently.

change.subject: Section 6
change.quote: In determining what is proportionate for the purposes of subsection (2), the size and capacity of the provider of a service, in particular, is relevant.
change.summary: The proposed change states that the size and capacity of the internet service provider should be taken into account when determining what is proportionate in relation to the duty mentioned in subsection (2).

change.subject: Section 7
change.quote: For the purposes of this section content is “content of democratic importance”, in relation to a user-to-user service, if— (a) the content is— (i) news publisher content in relation to that service, or (ii) regulated user-generated content in relation to that service; and (b) the content is or appears to be specifically intended to contribute to democratic political debate in the United Kingdom or a part or area of the United Kingdom.
change.summary: The proposed change defines "content of democratic importance" in relation to a user-to-user service as news publisher content or regulated user-generated content that is specifically intended to contribute to democratic political debate in the United Kingdom.

change.subject: Section 8
change.quote: In this section, the reference to “taking action” against a user is to giving a warning to a user, or suspending or banning a user from using a service, or in any way restricting a user’s ability to use a service.
change.summary: The proposed change clarifies that "taking action" against a user includes giving a warning, suspending or banning the user, or restricting their ability to use the service.

change.subject: Section 9
change.quote: For the meaning of “news publisher content” and “regulated user-generated content”, see section 55.
change.summary: The proposed change refers to section 55 for the definitions of "news publisher content" and "regulated user-generated content".

change.subject: Section 18(1)
change.quote: This section sets out the duties to protect news publisher content which apply in relation to Category 1 services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties to protect news publisher content that apply to Category 1 services.

change.subject: Section 19(1)
change.quote: This section sets out the duties to protect journalistic content which apply in relation to Category 1 services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties to protect journalistic content that apply to Category 1 services.

change.subject: Section 20(1)
change.quote: This section sets out the duty about content reporting which applies in relation to all regulated user-to-user services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty about content reporting that applies to all regulated user-to-user services.

change.subject: Section 21(1)
change.quote: This section sets out the duties about complaints procedures which apply in relation to all regulated user-to-user services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties about complaints procedures that apply to all regulated user-to-user services.

change.subject: Section 22(1)
change.quote: This section sets out the duties about freedom of expression and privacy which apply in relation to regulated user-to-user services (as indicated by the headings).
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties about freedom of expression and privacy that apply to regulated user-to-user services.

change.subject: Section 5
change.quote: (5) An impact assessment relating to a service must include a section which considers the impact of the safety measures and policies on the availability and treatment on the service of content which is news publisher content or journalistic content in relation to the service.
change.summary: The proposed change requires that an impact assessment relating to a service must include a section that considers the impact of safety measures and policies on the availability and treatment of news publisher content or journalistic content.

change.subject: Section 6
change.quote: (6) A duty to— (a) keep an impact assessment up to date, and (b) publish impact assessments.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty to keep an impact assessment up to date and to publish impact assessments.

change.subject: Section 7
change.quote: (7) A duty to specify in a publicly available statement the positive steps that the provider has taken in response to an impact assessment to— (a) protect users’ right to freedom of expression within the law, and (b) protect the privacy of users.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty to specify in a publicly available statement the positive steps taken by the provider in response to an impact assessment to protect users' right to freedom of expression and privacy.

change.subject: Section 8
change.quote: (8) In this section— “impact assessment” means an impact assessment under subsection (4); “safety measures and policies” means measures and policies designed to secure compliance with any of the duties set out in— (a) section 10 (illegal content), (b) section 12 (children’s online safety), (c) section 15 (user empowerment), (d) section 20 (content reporting), or (e) section 21 (complaints procedures).
change.summary: The proposed change provides definitions for "impact assessment" and "safety measures and policies" in this section.

change.subject: Section 9
change.quote: (9) Any reference in this section to the privacy of users or steps taken to protect the privacy of users is to be construed in accordance with subsection (3).
change.summary: The proposed change clarifies that any reference to the privacy of users or steps taken to protect privacy should be interpreted in accordance with subsection (3).

change.subject: Section 10
change.summary: The proposed change refers the reader to section 19 for the meaning of "journalistic content" and section 55 for the meaning of "news publisher content".

change.subject: Section 23
change.quote: (1) This section sets out the record-keeping and review duties which apply in relation to regulated user-to-user services (as indicated by the headings).
change.summary: The proposed change sets out the record-keeping and review duties that apply to regulated user-to-user services.

change.subject: Section 24
change.quote: (2) A duty to make and keep a written record, in an easily understandable form, of all aspects of every risk assessment under section 9 or 11, including details about how the assessment was carried out and its findings.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty to make and keep a written record of all aspects of every risk assessment under section 9 or 11, including details about how the assessment was carried out and its findings.

change.subject: Section 27
change.quote: (5) If alternative measures have been taken or are in use to comply with a duty set out in section 10(2) or (3) or 12(2) or (3), the record required under subsection (4) of this section must also indicate whether such measures have been taken or are in use in every area listed in section 10(4) or 12(8) (as the case may be) in relation to which there are applicable measures in a code of practice.
change.summary: The proposed change requires that if alternative measures have been taken or are in use to comply with a duty set out in section 10(2) or (3) or 12(2) or (3), the record must indicate whether such measures have been taken or are in use in every relevant area listed in section 10(4) or 12(8).

change.subject: Section 28
change.quote: (9) A duty to summarise in a publicly available statement the findings of the most recent illegal content risk assessment of a service (including as to levels of risk and as to nature, and severity, of potential harm to individuals).
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty to summarize the findings of the most recent illegal content risk assessment of a service in a publicly available statement.

change.subject: Section 29
change.quote: (5) A duty to include provisions in a publicly available statement specifying how children are to be protected from search content of the following kinds— (a) primary priority content that is harmful to children (with each kind of primary priority content separately covered), (b) priority content that is harmful to children (with each kind of priority content separately covered), and (c) non-designated content that is harmful to children.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty to include provisions in a publicly available statement specifying how children are to be protected from search content that is harmful to children.

change.subject: Section 7
change.quote: (7) A duty to include provisions in a publicly available statement giving information about any proactive technology used by a service for the purpose of compliance with a duty set out in subsection (2) or (3) (including the kind of technology, when it is used, and how it works).
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty for service providers to include provisions in a publicly available statement that provides information about any proactive technology used by the service to comply with a duty set out in subsection (2) or (3).

change.subject: Section 8
change.quote: (8) A duty to ensure that the provisions of the publicly available statement referred to in subsections (5) and (7) are clear and accessible.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty for service providers to ensure that the provisions of the publicly available statement, as mentioned in subsections (5) and (7), are clear and accessible.

change.subject: Section 9
change.quote: (9) A duty to summarise in a publicly available statement the findings of the most recent children’s risk assessment of a service (including as to levels of risk and as to nature, and severity, of potential harm to children).
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty for service providers to include a summary of the findings of the most recent children's risk assessment of a service in a publicly available statement. This includes information about the levels of risk and the nature and severity of potential harm to children.

change.subject: Section 31
change.quote: (1) This section sets out the duty about content reporting which applies in relation to all regulated search services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty about content reporting that applies to all regulated search services.

change.subject: Section 32
change.quote: (1) This section sets out the duties about complaints procedures which apply in relation to all regulated search services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties about complaints procedures that apply to all regulated search services.

change.subject: Section 33
change.quote: (1) This section sets out the duties about freedom of expression and privacy which apply in relation to all regulated search services.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties about freedom of expression and privacy that apply to all regulated search services.

change.subject: Section 34
change.quote: (1) This section sets out the record-keeping and review duties which apply in relation to regulated search services (as indicated by the headings).
change.summary: The proposed change introduces record-keeping and review duties that apply to regulated search services.

change.subject: Section 35
change.quote: (1) In this Part, a “children’s access assessment” means an assessment of a Part 3 service— (a) to determine whether it is possible for children to access the service or a part of the service, and (b) if it is possible for children to access the service or a part of the service, to determine whether the child user condition is met in relation to the service or a part of the service.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces the definition of a "children's access assessment" as an assessment of a Part 3 service to determine if children can access the service and if the child user condition is met.

change.subject: Section 36
change.quote: (1) A provider of a Part 3 service must carry out the first children’s access assessment at a time set out in, or as provided by, Schedule 3.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a duty for providers of Part 3 services to carry out the first children's access assessment at a specified time.

change.subject: Section 38
change.quote: (1) A provider of a Category 1 service must operate the service using proportionate systems and processes designed to— (a) prevent individuals from encountering content consisting of fraudulent advertisements by means of the service; (b) minimise the length of time for which any such content is present; (c) where the provider is alerted by a person to the presence of such content, or becomes aware of it in any other way, swiftly take down such content.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties for providers of Category 1 services to operate the service using proportionate systems and processes to prevent individuals from encountering fraudulent advertisements, minimize the duration of such content, and promptly remove such content when alerted or aware of its presence.

change.subject: Section 39 Duties about fraudulent advertising: Category 2A services
change.quote: (1) A provider of a Category 2A service must operate the service using proportionate systems and processes designed to— (a) prevent individuals from encountering content consisting of fraudulent advertisements in or via search results of the service; (b) if any such content may be encountered in or via search results of the service, minimise the length of time that that is the case; (c) where the provider is alerted by a person to the fact that such content may be so encountered, or becomes aware of that fact in any other way, swiftly ensure that individuals are no longer able to encounter such content in or via search results of the service. (2) A provider of a Category 2A service must include clear and accessible provisions in a publicly available statement giving information about any proactive technology used by the service for the purpose of compliance with the duty set out in subsection (1) (including the kind of technology, when it is used, and how it works). (3) In relation to a Category 2A service, an advertisement is a “fraudulent advertisement” if— (a) it is a paid-for advertisement (see section 237), and (b) it amounts to an offence specified in section 40 (construed in accordance with section 59: see subsections (3), (11) and (12) of that section).
change.summary: The proposed change introduces duties for providers of Category 2A services to operate their services using proportionate systems and processes to prevent individuals from encountering fraudulent advertisements in search results. Providers must also include clear and accessible provisions in a publicly available statement regarding any proactive technology used for compliance. An advertisement is considered fraudulent if it is a paid-for advertisement and amounts to an offense specified in section 40.

change.subject: Section 40 Fraud etc offences
change.summary: The proposed change specifies various offenses for the purposes of the Chapter on fraudulent advertising, including offenses under the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000, the Fraud Act 2006, the Financial Services Act 2012, the Serious Crime Act 2007, and aiding, abetting, counseling, or procuring the commission of such offenses.

change.subject: Section 41 Codes of practice about duties
change.quote: (1) OFCOM must prepare and issue a code of practice for providers of Part 3 services describing measures recommended for the purpose of compliance with duties set out in section 10 or 27 (illegal content) so far as relating to terrorism content or offences within Schedule 5 (terrorism offences). (2) OFCOM must prepare and issue a code of practice for providers of Part 3 services describing measures recommended for the purpose of compliance with duties set out in section 10 or 27 (illegal content) so far as relating to CSEA content or offences within Schedule 6 (child sexual exploitation and abuse offences). (3) OFCOM must prepare and issue one or more codes of practice for providers of Part 3 services describing measures recommended for the purpose of compliance with the relevant duties (except to the extent that measures for the purpose of compliance with such duties are described in a code of practice prepared under subsection (1) or (2)). (4) OFCOM must prepare and issue a code of practice for providers of Category 1 services and providers of Category 2A services describing measures recommended for the purpose of compliance with the duties set out in Chapter 5 (fraudulent advertising).
change.summary: The proposed change requires OFCOM to prepare and issue codes of practice for providers of Part 3 services, including measures for compliance with duties related to illegal content, terrorism content, child sexual exploitation and abuse offenses, and fraudulent advertising.

change.subject: Section 42 Codes of practice: principles, objectives, content
change.quote: Schedule 4 contains— (a) provision about the principles OFCOM must consider when preparing codes of practice under section 41, (b) the online safety objectives (and a power for the Secretary of State by regulations to revise those objectives), (c) provision about the measures that may be described in codes of practice (including, in particular, constraints on the recommendation of the use of proactive technology), and (d) other provision related to codes of practice.
change.summary: The proposed change includes provisions in Schedule 4 that outline the principles OFCOM must consider when preparing codes of practice, the online safety objectives, measures that may be described in codes of practice (including constraints on recommending the use of proactive technology), and other related provisions.

change.subject: Section 43 Procedure for issuing codes of practice
change.quote: (1) Where OFCOM have prepared a draft of a code of practice under section 41, they must submit the draft to the Secretary of State. (2) Unless the Secretary of State intends to give a direction to OFCOM under section 44(1), (2) or (3) in relation to the draft, the Secretary of State must, as soon as reasonably practicable, lay the draft before Parliament. (3) If, within the 40-day period, either House of Parliament resolves not to approve the draft— (a) OFCOM must not issue the code of practice in the form of that draft, and (b) OFCOM must prepare another draft of the code of practice under section 41. (4) If no such resolution is made within that period— (a) OFCOM must issue the code of practice in the form of the draft laid before Parliament, and (b) the code of practice comes into force at the end of the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which it is issued.
change.summary: The proposed change outlines the procedure for issuing codes of practice, including the submission of a draft to the Secretary of State, laying the draft before Parliament, and the consequences if either House of Parliament resolves not to approve the draft.

change.subject: Section 44 Secretary of State’s powers of direction
change.quote: (1) The Secretary of State may direct OFCOM to modify a draft of a code of practice submitted under section 43(1) if the Secretary of State believes that modifications are required for the purpose of securing compliance with an international obligation of the United Kingdom. (2) The Secretary of State may direct OFCOM to modify a draft of a code of practice, other than a terrorism or CSEA code of practice, submitted under section 43(1) if the Secretary of State believes that modifications are required for exceptional reasons relating to— (a) national security, (b) public safety, (c) public health, or (d) relations with the government of a country outside the United Kingdom. (3) The Secretary of State may direct OFCOM to modify a draft of a terrorism or CSEA code of practice submitted under section 43(1) if the Secretary of State believes that modifications are required— (a) for reasons of national security or public safety, or (b) for exceptional reasons relating to public health or relations with the government of a country outside the United Kingdom.
change.summary: The proposed change grants the Secretary of State the power to direct OFCOM to modify a draft of a code of practice for the purpose of securing compliance with international obligations, exceptional reasons relating to national security, public safety, public health, or relations with a foreign government.

change.subject: Section 45 Procedure for issuing codes of practice following direction under section 44
change.quote: (2) If the draft contains modifications made following a direction given under section 44(1), (2) or (3)(b), the affirmative procedure applies. (3) If the draft contains modifications made following a direction given under section 44(3)(a), (4) or (5), the negative procedure applies.
change.summary: The proposed change specifies that the affirmative procedure applies if the draft of a code of practice contains modifications made following a direction given under section 44(1), (2), or (3)(b), while the negative procedure applies if the draft contains modifications made following a direction given under section 44(3)(a), (4), or (5).

change.subject: Establishment of new institutions
change.quote: (1) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services to assist them in complying with their duties set out in section 14 (assessments related to the adult user empowerment duty set out in section 15(2)).
(2) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services to assist them in complying with their duties set out in section 18 (news publisher content).

(3) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Part 3 services to assist them in complying with their duties set out in section 23 or 34, except the duty set out in subsection (9) of those sections (record-keeping and review), and their duties set out in section 36 (children’s access assessments).
change.summary: The bill proposes the establishment of new guidance produced by OFCOM to assist providers of Category 1 services and Part 3 services in complying with their duties related to adult user empowerment, news publisher content, record-keeping and review, and children's access assessments.

change.subject: Expansion of individual rights
change.quote: (1) A provider of a Part 3 service is to be treated as complying with a relevant duty if the provider takes or uses the measures described in a code of practice which are recommended for the purpose of compliance with the duty in question.
change.summary: The bill expands individual rights by stating that providers of Part 3 services, user-to-user services, and search services will be considered compliant with their duties if they take or use measures recommended in a code of practice that incorporate safeguards for freedom of expression and privacy.

change.subject: Expansion of individual rights
change.quote: (5) A provider of a Part 3 service who seeks to comply with a relevant duty by acting otherwise than by taking or using a measure described in a code of practice or a fraudulent advertising code of practice which is recommended for the purpose of compliance with the duty must have particular regard to the importance of the following (where relevant)— (a) protecting the right of users and (in the case of search services) interested persons to freedom of expression within the law, and (b) protecting the privacy of users.

(6) When assessing whether a provider of a Part 3 service is compliant with a relevant duty where the provider has acted otherwise than by taking or using a measure described in a code of practice or a fraudulent advertising code of practice which is recommended for the purpose of compliance with the duty, OFCOM must consider the extent to which the alternative measures taken or in use by the provider— (a) extend across all areas of a service as mentioned in section 10(4), 12(5), 27(4) or 29(4) (if relevant to the duty in question), and (b) (where appropriate) incorporate safeguards for the protection of the matters mentioned in subsection (5)(a) and (b).
change.summary: The bill emphasizes the importance of protecting the right to freedom of expression and privacy for providers of Part 3 services who choose to comply with their duties in ways other than those described in a code of practice.

change.subject: Expansion of individual rights
change.quote: (1) A failure by a provider of a Part 3 service to act in accordance with a provision of a code of practice does not of itself make the provider liable to legal proceedings in a court or tribunal.
(2) A code of practice is admissible in evidence in legal proceedings.

(3) In any proceedings in a court or tribunal, the court or tribunal must take into account a provision of a code of practice in determining a question arising in the proceedings if— (a) the question relates to a time when the provision was in force, and (b) the provision appears to the court or tribunal to be relevant to the question.

(4) OFCOM must take into account a provision of a code of practice in determining a question arising in connection with their exercise of any relevant function if— (a) the question relates to a time when the provision was in force, and (b) the provision appears to OFCOM to be relevant to the question.
change.summary: The bill clarifies that a failure to comply with a code of practice does not automatically make a provider of a Part 3 service liable to legal proceedings. It also states that codes of practice are admissible as evidence in legal proceedings and must be taken into account by courts, tribunals, and OFCOM in determining relevant questions.

change.subject: Expansion of individual rights
change.quote: (1) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Part 3 services which contains examples of content or kinds of content that OFCOM consider to be, or consider not to be— (a) primary priority content that is harmful to children, or (b) priority content that is harmful to children.

(2) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services which contains examples of content or kinds of content that OFCOM consider to be, or consider not to be, content to which section 15(2) applies (see section 16).
change.summary: The bill requires OFCOM to produce guidance for providers of Part 3 services and Category 1 services that includes examples of content that is considered harmful to children and content to which section 15(2) (related to user empowerment) applies.

change.subject: Expansion of individual rights
change.quote: (1) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Part 3 services which focuses on content and activity— (a) in relation to which such providers have duties set out in this Part or Part 4, and (b) which disproportionately affects women and girls.
change.summary: The bill requires OFCOM to produce guidance for providers of Part 3 services that focuses on content and activity that disproportionately affects women and girls. The guidance may include advice, examples of best practice, and references to relevant provisions in a code of practice.

change.subject: subsection (6)
change.quote: "provider content” means content published on a service by the provider of the service or by a person acting on behalf of the provider, including where the publication of the content is effected or controlled by means of— (a) software or an automated tool or algorithm applied by the provider or by a person acting on behalf of the provider, or (b) an automated tool or algorithm made available on the service by the provider or by a person acting on behalf of the provider."
change.summary: Amendment to the definition of "provider content" to include content published by a person acting on behalf of the provider and content controlled by software or automated tools.

change.subject: subsection (9)
change.quote: "Content is within this subsection if it was generated directly on the service by a user of the service that is a recognised news publisher."
change.summary: Amendment to define "news publisher content" as content generated directly on the service by a user who is a recognised news publisher.

change.subject: subsection (10)
change.quote: "Content is within this subsection if— (a) the content was uploaded to or shared on the service by a user of the service, and (b) the content either— (i) reproduces in full an article or written item that was originally published by a recognised news publisher (and is not a screenshot or photograph of that article or item or of part of it), (ii) is video or audio content that was originally published or broadcast by a recognised news publisher, and is not a clipped or edited form of such content (unless it is the recognised news publisher who has clipped or edited it), or (iii) is a link to an article or item within sub-paragraph (i) or to content within sub-paragraph (ii)."
change.summary: Amendment to define the types of content that fall under "news publisher content" including reproductions of articles, video or audio content, and links to articles or content.

change.subject: section 56
change.quote: "In this Part, “recognised news publisher” means any of the following entities— (a) the British Broadcasting Corporation, (b) Sianel Pedwar Cymru, (c) the holder of a licence under the Broadcasting Act 1990 or 1996 who publishes news-related material in connection with the broadcasting activities authorised under the licence, and (d) any other entity which— (i) meets all of the conditions in subsection (2), (ii) is not an excluded entity (see subsection (3)), and (iii) is not a sanctioned entity (see subsection (4))."
change.summary: Amendment to define "recognised news publisher" as specific entities including the British Broadcasting Corporation, Sianel Pedwar Cymru, and holders of broadcasting licenses who publish news-related material.

change.subject: section 59
change.quote: "“Illegal content” means content that amounts to a relevant offence."
change.summary: Amendment to define "illegal content" as content that amounts to a relevant offence.

change.subject: section 60
change.quote: "“Content that is harmful to children” means— (a) primary priority content that is harmful to children (see section 61), (b) priority content that is harmful to children (see section 62), or (c) content, not within paragraph (a) or (b), of a kind which presents a material risk of significant harm to an appreciable number of children in the United Kingdom."
change.summary: Amendment to define "content that is harmful to children" as primary priority content, priority content, or content that presents a material risk of significant harm to children.

change.subject: subsection 11
change.quote: For the purposes of subsection (3), a person has the characteristic of gender reassignment if the person is proposing to undergo, is undergoing or has undergone a process (or part of a process) for the purpose of reassigning the person’s sex by changing physiological or other attributes of sex, and the reference to gender reassignment in subsection (2) is to be construed accordingly.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies the definition of gender reassignment for the purposes of the Act.

change.subject: subsection 12
change.summary: The insertion provides a definition of "bullying content" for the purposes of the Act.

change.subject: subsection 13
change.quote: In subsection (6) “person” is not limited to a real person.
change.summary: The insertion clarifies that the term "person" in subsection (6) is not limited to a real person.

change.subject: subsection 14
change.quote: In subsection (7) “animal” is not limited to a real animal.
change.summary: The insertion clarifies that the term "animal" in subsection (7) is not limited to a real animal.

change.subject: section 63
change.quote: OFCOM must carry out reviews of— (a) the incidence on regulated user-to-user services of content that is harmful to children, (b) the incidence on regulated search services and combined services of search content that is harmful to children, and (c) the severity of harm that children in the United Kingdom suffer, or may suffer, as a result of those kinds of content.
change.summary: The insertion requires OFCOM to conduct reviews of the incidence of harmful content to children on regulated user-to-user services and search services.

change.subject: section 65
change.quote: A provider of a Category 1 service must offer all adult users of the service the option to verify their identity (if identity verification is not required for access to the service).
change.summary: The insertion requires providers of Category 1 services to offer adult users the option to verify their identity.

change.subject: section 66
change.quote: OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services to assist them in complying with the duty set out in section 65(1).
change.summary: The insertion requires OFCOM to produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services on identity verification.

change.subject: section 67
change.quote: A UK provider of a regulated user-to-user service must operate the service using systems and processes which secure (so far as possible) that the provider reports all detected and unreported CSEA content present on the service to the NCA.
change.summary: The insertion requires UK providers of regulated user-to-user services to report all detected and unreported child sexual exploitation and abuse (CSEA) content to the NCA.

change.subject: section 68
change.quote: The Secretary of State must make regulations in connection with the reports that are to be made to the NCA (including by non-UK providers) as required by section 67.
change.summary: The insertion requires the Secretary of State to make regulations regarding the reports to be made to the NCA regarding child sexual exploitation and abuse (CSEA) content.

change.subject: section 70
change.quote: A person commits an offence if, in purported compliance with a requirement under section 67— (a) the person provides information that is false in a material respect, and (b) at the time the person provides it, the person knows that it is false in a material respect or is reckless as to whether it is false in a material respect.
change.summary: The insertion creates an offence for providing false information in compliance with a requirement under section 67.

change.subject: section 72
change.quote: A provider of a Category 1 service must operate the service using proportionate systems and processes designed to ensure that the provider does not— (a) take down regulated user-generated content from the service, (b) restrict users’ access to regulated user-generated content, or (c) suspend or ban users from using the service, except in accordance with the terms of service.
change.summary: The insertion requires providers of Category 1 services to operate the service in accordance with the terms of service when taking down content, restricting access, or suspending/banning users.

change.subject: section 73
change.quote: A provider of a regulated user-to-user service must include clear and accessible provisions in the terms of service informing users about their right to bring a claim for breach of contract if— (a) regulated user-generated content which they generate, upload or share is taken down, or access to it is restricted, in breach of the terms of service, or (b) they are suspended or banned from using the service in breach of the terms of service.
change.summary: The insertion requires providers of regulated user-to-user services to inform users about their right to bring a claim for breach of contract if their content is taken down or access is restricted, or if they are suspended or banned in breach of the terms of service.

change.subject: subsection 9
change.quote: (9) The duties set out in subsections (3) and (4) do not apply in relation to terms of service which—
change.summary: The proposed amendment states that the duties set out in subsections (3) and (4) do not apply to certain terms of service.

change.subject: subsection 10
change.quote: (10) If a person is the provider of more than one regulated user-to-user service or Category 1 service, the duties set out in this section apply in relation to each such service.
change.summary: The proposed insertion states that if a person is the provider of multiple regulated user-to-user services or Category 1 services, the duties set out in this section apply to each service.

change.subject: subsection 11
change.quote: (11) The duties set out in this section extend only to the design, operation and use of a service in the United Kingdom, and references to users are to United Kingdom users of a service.
change.summary: The proposed insertion states that the duties set out in this section only apply to the design, operation, and use of a service in the United Kingdom, and references to users are specifically referring to United Kingdom users.

change.subject: section 74
change.quote: (1) OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services to assist them in complying with their duties set out in sections 72 and 73(3) to (7). (2) OFCOM must publish the guidance (and any revised or replacement guidance).
change.summary: The proposed insertion states that OFCOM must produce guidance for providers of Category 1 services to assist them in complying with their duties set out in sections 72 and 73(3) to (7), and OFCOM must publish the guidance.

change.subject: section 76
change.quote: (1) A provider of a relevant service must make it clear in the terms of service what their policy is about dealing with requests from parents of a deceased child for information about the child’s use of the service. (2) A provider of a relevant service must have a dedicated helpline or section of the service, or some similar means, by which parents can easily find out what they need to do to obtain information and updates in those circumstances, and the terms of service must provide details. (3) A provider of a relevant service must include clear and accessible provisions in the terms of service— (a) specifying the procedure for parents of a deceased child to request information about the child’s use of the service, (b) specifying what evidence (if any) the provider will require about the parent’s identity or relationship to the child, and (c) giving sufficient detail to enable child users and their parents to be reasonably certain about what kinds of information would be disclosed and how information would be disclosed. (4) A provider of a relevant service must respond in a timely manner to requests from parents of a deceased child for information about the child’s use of the service or for updates about the progress of such information requests. (5) A provider of a relevant service must operate a complaints procedure in relation to the service that— (a) allows for complaints to be made by parents of a deceased child who consider that the provider is not complying with a duty set out in any of subsections (1) to (4), (b) provides for appropriate action to be taken by the provider of the service in response to such complaints, and (c) is easy to access, easy to use and transparent.
change.summary: The proposed insertion states that providers of relevant services must have policies and provisions in place for dealing with requests from parents of deceased children for information about the child's use of the service, including a dedicated helpline or section of the service, clear procedures for requesting information, and a timely response to requests. Providers must also operate a complaints procedure that is accessible, easy to use, and transparent.

change.subject: section 78
change.quote: (1) Once a year, OFCOM must give every provider of a relevant service a notice which requires the provider to produce a report about the service (a “transparency report”). (2) If a person is the provider of more than one relevant service, a notice must be given to the provider in respect of each such service. (3) In response to a notice relating to a relevant service, the provider of the service must produce a transparency report which must— (a) contain information of a kind specified or described in the notice, (b) be in the format specified in the notice, (c) be submitted to OFCOM by the date specified in the notice, and (d) be published in the manner and by the date specified in the notice. (4) A provider must ensure that the information provided in a transparency report is— (a) complete, and (b) accurate in all material respects.
change.summary: The proposed insertion states that OFCOM must give providers of relevant services a notice requiring them to produce a transparency report about the service once a year. The report must contain specified information, be submitted to OFCOM by a specified date, and be published in a specified manner. Providers must ensure that the information provided in the report is complete and accurate.

change.subject: section 82
change.quote: (2) A duty to ensure, by the use of age verification or age estimation (or both), that children are not normally able to encounter content that is regulated provider pornographic content in relation to the service. (3) The age verification or age estimation must be of such a kind, and used in such a way, that it is highly effective at correctly determining whether or not a particular user is a child. (4) In relation to the duty set out in subsection (2), a duty to make and keep a written record, in an easily understandable form, of— (a) the kinds of age verification or age estimation used, and how they are used, and (b) the way in which the provider, when deciding on the kinds of age verification or age estimation and how they should be used, has had regard to the importance of protecting United Kingdom users from a breach of any statutory provision or rule of law concerning privacy that is relevant to the use or operation of a regulated service (including, but not limited to, any such provision or rule concerning the processing of personal data). (5) A duty to summarise the written record in a publicly available statement, so far as the record concerns compliance with the duty set out in subsection (2), including details about which kinds of age verification or age estimation a provider is using and how they are used.
change.summary: The proposed insertion states that providers of internet services must ensure that children are not normally able to encounter regulated provider pornographic content by using age verification or age estimation. Providers must keep a written record of the kinds of age verification or age estimation used and how they are used, and consider the importance of protecting users' privacy when deciding on the methods. Providers must also summarize the written record in a publicly available statement.

change.subject: subsection 3(2)(g)
change.quote: (g) the adequate protection of citizens from harm presented by content on regulated services, through the appropriate use by providers of such services of systems and processes designed to reduce the risk of such harm.
change.summary: The proposed change adds a new duty for OFCOM to ensure the adequate protection of citizens from harm presented by content on regulated services. Providers of regulated services are required to use systems and processes designed to reduce the risk of harm.

change.subject: subsection 3(4A)
change.summary: This proposed change outlines the factors that OFCOM must consider when performing their duties related to the protection of citizens from harm on regulated services. These factors include the risk of harm, the need for higher protection for children, the clarity of compliance requirements for providers, the proportionality of measures taken by providers, the promotion of technologies to reduce harm, and the transparency and accountability of providers in complying with their duties.

change.subject: Section 7 of the Communications Act
change.quote: (1) Section 7 of the Communications Act (duty to carry out impact assessments) is amended as follows.
(2) In subsection (2), at the beginning insert “Subject to subsection (2A),”.

(3) After subsection (2) insert—“(2A) A proposal to do any of the following is important for the purposes of this section—(a) to prepare a code of practice under section 41 of the Online Safety Act 2023;(b) to prepare amendments of such a code of practice; or(c) to prepare a code of practice as a replacement for such a code of practice.”

(4) After subsection (4) insert—“(4A) An assessment under subsection (3)(a) that relates to a proposal mentioned in subsection (2A) must include an assessment of the likely impact of implementing the proposal on small businesses and micro businesses.(4B) An assessment under subsection (3)(a) that relates to a proposal to do anything else for the purposes of, or in connection with, the carrying out of OFCOM’s online safety functions (within the meaning of section 236 of the Online Safety Act 2023) must, so far as the proposal relates to such functions, include an assessment of the likely impact of implementing the proposal on small businesses and micro businesses.”
change.summary: Section 7 of the Communications Act is amended to include provisions for impact assessments related to the preparation of codes of practice under the Online Safety Act 2023 and the likely impact on small businesses and micro businesses.

change.subject: Chapter 2 - Register of categories of regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services
change.quote: (1) Schedule 11 contains provision about regulations specifying the threshold conditions that a Part 3 service must meet to be included in the relevant part of the register established by OFCOM under section 96, and associated provision about the publication of OFCOM’s advice.

(2) In this Chapter, “Category 1 threshold conditions”, “Category 2A threshold conditions” and “Category 2B threshold conditions” have the same meaning as in Schedule 11 (see paragraph 1(1), (2) and (3) of that Schedule).

(3) For the purposes of this Chapter—(a) a regulated user-to-user service meets the Category 1 threshold conditions if those conditions are met in relation to the user-to-user part of the service;(b) a regulated search service or a combined service meets the Category 2A threshold conditions if those conditions are met in relation to the search engine of the service;(c) a regulated user-to-user service meets the Category 2B threshold conditions if those conditions are met in relation to the user-to-user part of the service;(d) a regulated user-to-user service meets the conditions in section 98(2) if those conditions are met in relation to the user-to-user part of the service;(e) references to OFCOM assessing a service (to determine if it meets, or no longer meets, the relevant threshold conditions or the conditions in section 98(2)) are accordingly to be read as references to OFCOM assessing the relevant part (or parts) of a service.
(4) If OFCOM consider that a service meets the relevant threshold conditions, they must add entries relating to that service to the relevant part of the register established under subsection (2).

(5) But—(a) if OFCOM consider that a regulated user-to-user service meets the Category 1 threshold conditions and the Category 2B threshold conditions (only), entries relating to that service are to be added to the part of the register established under subsection (2)(a) (only);(b) if OFCOM consider that a combined service meets the Category 1 threshold conditions, the Category 2A threshold conditions and the Category 2B threshold conditions, entries relating to that service are to be added to the parts of the register established under subsection (2)(a) and (b) (only).

(6) If OFCOM consider that a combined service—(a) meets the Category 2A threshold conditions, and(b) meets either the Category 1 threshold conditions or the Category 2B threshold conditions (but not both),entries relating to that service are to be added to the part of the register established under subsection (2)(b) and to the part of the register established under subsection (2)(a) or (c) (whichever applies).

(7) Each part of the register must contain—(a) the name, and a description, of each service that, in OFCOM’s opinion, meets the relevant threshold conditions, and(b) the name of the provider of each such service.
(8) OFCOM must publish the register.

(9) When assessing whether a Part 3 service does, or does not, meet the relevant threshold conditions, OFCOM must take such steps as are reasonably practicable to obtain or generate information or evidence for the purposes of the assessment.

(10) In this Act—(a) a “Category 1 service” means a regulated user-to-user service for the time being included in the part of the register established under subsection (2)(a);(b) a “Category 2A service” means a regulated search service or a combined service for the time being included in the part of the register established under subsection (2)(b);(c) a “Category 2B service” means a regulated user-to-user service for the time being included in the part of the register established under subsection (2)(c).
change.summary: A new chapter is inserted to establish a register of categories of regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services. The register will contain information about services that meet the relevant threshold conditions and will be published by OFCOM.

change.subject: Chapter 3 - Risk assessments of regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services
change.quote: (1) OFCOM must carry out risk assessments to identify and assess the following risks of harm presented by Part 3 services of different kinds—(a) the risks of harm to individuals in the United Kingdom presented by illegal content present on regulated user-to-user services and by the use of such services for the commission or facilitation of priority offences;(b) the risk of harm to individuals in the United Kingdom presented by search content of regulated search services that is illegal content;(c) the risk of harm to children in the United Kingdom, in different age groups, presented by content that is harmful to children.

(2) The risk assessments must, among other things, identify characteristics of different kinds of Part 3 services that are relevant to such risks of harm, and assess the impact of those kinds of characteristics on such risks.

(3) OFCOM—(a) may combine assessment of any or all of the risks of harm mentioned in subsection (1), or may carry out separate assessments of those risks;(b) in the case of the risk of harm mentioned in subsection (1)(c), may assess regulated user-to-user services and regulated search services separately or together.
(4) The findings of each risk assessment are to be reflected, as soon as reasonably practicable after completion, in a register of risks of Part 3 services prepared and published by OFCOM.

(5) As soon as reasonably practicable after completing their assessment of a risk of harm mentioned in a particular paragraph of subsection (1), OFCOM must prepare risk profiles for Part 3 services which relate to that risk of harm.

(6) For the purposes of the risk profiles, OFCOM may group Part 3 services together in whichever way they consider appropriate, taking into account—(a) the characteristics of the services, and(b) the risk levels and other matters identified in the relevant risk assessment.
(7) OFCOM must publish risk profiles prepared under this section.
(8) OFCOM must from time to time review and revise the risk assessments and risk profiles so as to keep them up to date.
change.summary: A new chapter is inserted to require OFCOM to carry out risk assessments of different kinds of Part 3 services to identify and assess risks of harm to individuals in the UK and children. The findings of the risk assessments will be reflected in a register of risks and risk profiles prepared and published by OFCOM.

change.subject: Chapter 4 - Information powers and information notices
change.quote: (1) OFCOM may by notice under this subsection require a person within subsection (5) to provide them with any information that they require for the purpose of exercising, or deciding whether to exercise, any of their online safety functions.

(2) The power conferred by subsection (1) includes power to require a person within subsection (5) to—(a) obtain or generate information;(b) provide information about the use of a service by a named individual.
change.summary: A new chapter is inserted to grant OFCOM the power to require a person to provide them with any information necessary for the exercise of their online safety functions.

change.subject: subsection (1)
change.quote: The power conferred by subsection (1) also includes power to require a person within any of paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (5) to take steps so that OFCOM are able to remotely access the service provided by the person, or remotely access equipment used by the service provided by the person, in order to view, in particular—
information demonstrating in real time the operation of systems, processes or features, including functionalities and algorithms, used by the service;
information generated in real time by the performance of a test or demonstration of a kind required by a notice under subsection (1).
change.summary: The amendment grants OFCOM the power to require a person to take steps to allow remote access to their service or equipment for the purpose of viewing real-time information about the operation of systems, processes, features, functionalities, and algorithms used by the service. This includes information generated in real-time by tests or demonstrations required by a notice.

change.subject: subsection (4)
change.quote: But the power conferred by subsection (1) must be exercised in a way that is proportionate to the use to which the information is to be put in the exercise of OFCOM’s functions.
change.summary: The amendment specifies that the power granted in subsection (1) must be exercised in a proportionate manner based on the use of the information by OFCOM in carrying out their functions.

change.subject: subsection (5)
change.quote: The persons within this subsection are—
a provider of a user-to-user service or a search service,
a provider of an internet service on which regulated provider pornographic content is published or displayed,
a person who provides an ancillary service (within the meaning of section 145) in relation to a regulated service (see subsections (11) and (12) of that section),
a person who provides an access facility (within the meaning of section 147) in relation to a regulated service (see subsections (10) and (11) of that section),
a person who was within any of paragraphs (a) to (d) at a time to which the required information relates, and
a person not within any of paragraphs (a) to (e) who appears to OFCOM to have, or to be able to generate or obtain, information required by them as mentioned in subsection (1).
change.summary: The amendment specifies the persons who fall within the scope of this subsection, including providers of user-to-user services, search services, internet services with regulated provider pornographic content, ancillary service providers, and access facility providers. It also includes persons who were previously within these categories and persons who are not within these categories but have information required by OFCOM.

change.subject: subsection (6)
change.quote: The information that may be required by OFCOM under subsection (1) includes, in particular, information that they require for any one or more of the following purposes—
the purpose of assessing compliance with—
the purpose of assessing compliance with a requirement under section 84 (duty to notify OFCOM in relation to the charging of fees);
the purpose of a consultation about a threshold figure as mentioned in section 87 (threshold figure for the purposes of charging fees);
the purpose of ascertaining the amount of a person’s qualifying worldwide revenue for the purposes of—
the purpose of assessing compliance with any requirements imposed on a person by—
the purpose of assessing the accuracy and effectiveness of technology required to be used by—
the purpose of assessing whether to give a notice under section 122(1) relating to the development or sourcing of technology (see subsections (2)(b) and (3)(b) of that section);
the purpose of dealing with complaints made to OFCOM under section 170 (super-complaints);
the purpose of OFCOM’s advice to the Secretary of State about provision to be made by regulations under paragraph 1 of Schedule 11 (threshold conditions for categories of Part 3 services);
the purpose of determining whether a Part 3 service meets threshold conditions specified in regulations under paragraph 1 of Schedule 11;
the purpose of preparing a code of practice under section 41;
the purpose of preparing guidance in relation to online safety matters;
the purpose of carrying out research, or preparing a report, in relation to online safety matters;
the purpose of complying with OFCOM’s duties under section 11 of the Communications Act, so far as relating to regulated services (media literacy).
change.summary: The amendment expands the purposes for which OFCOM may require information under subsection (1), including assessing compliance with various duties and requirements, ascertaining revenue, assessing technology accuracy and effectiveness, dealing with complaints, providing advice to the Secretary of State, preparing codes of practice and guidance, conducting research, and complying with media literacy duties.

change.subject: subsection (8)
change.quote: The power conferred by subsection (1) does not include power to require the provision of information in respect of which a claim to legal professional privilege, or (in Scotland) to confidentiality of communications, could be maintained in legal proceedings.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that the power granted in subsection (1) does not extend to requiring the provision of information protected by legal professional privilege or confidentiality of communications in legal proceedings.

change.subject: subsection (10)
change.quote: OFCOM may by notice under this subsection require a relevant person to provide them with information for the purpose of—

responding to a notice given by a senior coroner under paragraph 1(2) of Schedule 5 to the Coroners and Justice Act 2009 in connection with an investigation into the death of a child, or preparing a report under section 164 in connection with such an investigation;

responding to a request for information in connection with the investigation of a procurator fiscal into, or an inquiry held or to be held in relation to, the death of a child, or preparing a report under section 164 in connection with such an inquiry;
responding to a notice given by a coroner under section 17A(2) of the Coroners Act (Northern Ireland) 1959 (c. 15 (N.I.)) in connection with—
an investigation to determine whether an inquest into the death of a child is necessary, or
