(3) An authorisation under this paragraph must be in writing.
change.summary: The proposed change grants OFCOM the power to authorize persons to exercise powers of entry, inspection, and audit.

change.subject: Power of entry and inspection without a warrant
change.quote: 2 (1) The powers conferred by this paragraph may be exercised in relation to premises only if OFCOM— (a) believe that the premises are being used by the provider of a regulated service in connection with the provision of a regulated service, and (b) have given the occupier of the premises seven days’ notice that they propose to exercise the powers. (2) The powers conferred by this paragraph must be exercised at a reasonable hour. (3) Before exercising a power of entry under this paragraph, an authorised person must, if requested to do so by a person on the premises— (a) produce evidence of the authorised person’s identity, and (b) outline the purpose for which the power is exercised. (4) An authorised person may— (a) enter the premises, (b) inspect the premises, (c) observe the carrying on of the regulated service at the premises, (d) inspect any document or equipment found on the premises, (e) require any person on the premises to provide any information, or produce any document in the person’s possession or control, that the authorised person considers is relevant to the provision of the regulated service, and (f) require any person on the premises to provide an explanation of any document or to state where it may be found.
change.summary: The proposed change grants OFCOM the power to enter and inspect premises without a warrant under certain conditions.

change.subject: Notice requiring information, documents or tests at inspection
change.quote: 3 (1) This paragraph applies where OFCOM intend to exercise the powers conferred by paragraph 2 to enter and inspect premises. (2) OFCOM may give the occupier of the premises a notice requiring relevant information to be provided, relevant documents to be produced, or a relevant test or demonstration to be performed, during the inspection. (3) Any such notice must be given at least seven days in advance of the proposed inspection date. (4) For the purposes of this paragraph, information or a document, test or demonstration is “relevant” if it is required in connection with the exercise by OFCOM of their functions under this Act.
change.summary: The proposed change allows OFCOM to give notices to the occupier of premises requiring the provision of information, documents, or tests during an inspection.

change.subject: Audit
change.quote: 4 (1) OFCOM may give the provider of a regulated service a notice (an “audit notice”) requiring the provider to permit OFCOM to carry out an audit— (a) to assess whether the provider has complied or is complying with enforceable requirements that apply in respect of the service, or (b) to assess— (i) the nature and level of risk of the provider failing to comply with an enforceable requirement that applies in respect of the service, and (ii) ways to mitigate such a risk. (2) An audit notice may require the provider to take any of the following actions for a purpose mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)— (a) to permit an authorised person to enter and inspect specified premises; (b) to permit an authorised person to observe the carrying on of the regulated service at the premises; (c) to direct an authorised person to documents on the premises that are of a specified description; (d) to assist an authorised person to view information of a specified description that is capable of being viewed using equipment or a device on the premises; (e) to assist an authorised person to view, using equipment or a device on the premises, information demonstrating in real time the operation of systems, processes or features of a specified description, including functionalities or algorithms of a specified description; (f) to assist an authorised person to view, using equipment or a device on the premises, information generated in real time by the performance of a test or demonstration of a specified description; (g) to comply with a request from an authorised person for a copy (in such form as may be requested) of the documents or information to which the person is directed or which the person is assisted to view; (h) to permit an authorised person to inspect the documents, information or equipment to which the person is directed or which the person is assisted to view; (i) to provide an authorised person with an explanation of such documents or information; (j) to make available for interview by the authorised person a specified number of people of a specified description who are involved in the provision of the regulated service (not exceeding the number who are willing to be interviewed).
change.summary: The proposed change allows OFCOM to give audit notices to regulated service providers, requiring them to permit audits and take specific actions for assessment purposes.

change.subject: Conditions for issue of a warrant
change.quote: 5 (1) A justice of the peace or (in Northern Ireland) a lay magistrate may issue a warrant in relation to premises specified in an application only if satisfied on sworn information in writing given by an authorised person that— (a) the premises are being used by the provider of a regulated service in connection with the provision of a regulated service; (b) there are reasonable grounds to suspect that— (i) the provider is failing to comply, or has failed to comply, with an enforceable requirement that applies in respect of that service, and (ii) there is information or equipment on the premises, or there are documents on the premises, relevant to OFCOM’s investigation into that failure (or possible failure); and (c) any of the conditions in sub-paragraph (2) are met.
change.summary: The proposed change outlines the conditions for issuing a warrant in relation to premises used by a regulated service provider.

change.subject: Powers exercisable by warrant
change.summary: The proposed change grants authorized persons executing a warrant various powers for the purpose of investigating failures related to regulated services.

change.subject: Offences
change.quote: 18 (1) A person commits an offence if— (a) the person intentionally obstructs a person acting under this Schedule; (b) the person fails, without reasonable excuse, to comply with any requirement imposed by a person acting under this Schedule; (c) in response to a requirement imposed by a person acting under this Schedule, the person provides information that is false in a material respect, knowing that it is false in a material respect or being reckless as to whether it is false in a material respect. (2) A person who commits an offence under this paragraph is liable— (a) on summary conviction in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding the general limit in a magistrates’ court or a fine (or both); (b) on summary conviction in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both); (c) on summary conviction in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both); (d) on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or a fine (or both).
change.summary: The proposed change outlines offenses related to obstructing or failing to comply with requirements imposed by persons acting under the schedule.

change.subject: Schedule 13 Section 144
change.summary: The definition of "penalty" in this schedule is expanded to include penalties imposed by confirmation decisions and penalty notices under various sections.

change.subject: Schedule 13 Section 265
change.quote: In determining the amount of a penalty to be imposed on a person, OFCOM must, in particular, take into account— (a) any representations made, and evidence provided, by the person, and (b) the effects of the failure (or failures) in respect of which the penalty is imposed.
change.summary: OFCOM must consider representations made by the person and the effects of the failure when determining the amount of a penalty to be imposed.

change.subject: Schedule 13 Section 265
change.quote: A penalty must be of an amount that OFCOM consider to be— (a) appropriate, and (b) proportionate to the failure (or failures) in respect of which it is imposed.
change.summary: The penalty must be considered appropriate and proportionate to the failure(s) it is imposed for.

change.subject: Schedule 13 Section 265
change.quote: See also section 392 of the Communications Act (which requires OFCOM to produce guidelines about their determination of the amount of penalties that they impose).
change.summary: OFCOM is required to produce guidelines about their determination of the amount of penalties they impose.

change.subject: Schedule 13 Section 265
change.quote: A confirmation decision or penalty notice may not impose a penalty of a different kind, of a greater amount or (in the case of a penalty calculated by reference to a daily rate) payable over a longer period than that proposed in the earlier notice in relation to the same matter.
change.summary: A confirmation decision or penalty notice cannot impose a penalty that is different in kind, greater in amount, or payable over a longer period than what was proposed in the earlier notice for the same matter.

change.subject: Schedule 13 Section 265
change.quote: The maximum amount of the penalty for which the entities are liable is whichever is the greater of— (a) £18 million, and (b) 10% of the qualifying worldwide revenue of the group of entities that consists of— (i) the entity that is the provider of the regulated service to which the decision or notice in question relates (“entity E”), and (ii) every other entity which (at the time the decision or notice is given) is a group undertaking in relation to entity E.
change.summary: The maximum amount of the penalty for which a group of entities is liable is the greater of £18 million or 10% of the qualifying worldwide revenue of the group.

change.subject: Schedule 14 Section 1
change.quote: In Schedule 1 to the Football Spectators Act 1989 (football banning orders: relevant offences), after paragraph 1(y) insert— “(z) any offence under section 180 (false communications) or 182 (threatening communications) of the Online Safety Act 2023— (i) which does not fall within paragraph (d), (e), (m), (n), (r) or (s), (ii) as respects which the court has stated that the offence is aggravated by hostility of any of the types mentioned in section 66(1) of the Sentencing Code (racial hostility etc), and (iii) as respects which the court makes a declaration that the offence related to a football match, to a football organisation or to a person whom the accused knew or believed to have a prescribed connection with a football organisation.”
change.summary: Offences under section 180 (false communications) or 182 (threatening communications) of the Online Safety Act 2023 can be considered relevant offences for football banning orders under certain conditions.

change.subject: Schedule 14 Section 2
change.quote: In Schedule 5 to the Sexual Offences Act 2003, in the list of offences for England and Wales, after paragraph 63C insert— “63D An offence under section 180 of the Online Safety Act 2023 (false communications). 63E An offence under section 182 of that Act (threatening communications).”
change.summary: Offences under section 180 (false communications) and section 182 (threatening communications) of the Online Safety Act 2023 are added to the list of offences under the Sexual Offences Act 2003.

change.subject: section 66B(3) of this Act
change.quote: "33B An offence under section 66B(3) of this Act (sharing intimate photograph or film for purpose of obtaining sexual gratification)"
change.summary: The proposed change is an amendment to section 66B(3) of the Act, which relates to the offense of sharing intimate photographs or films for the purpose of obtaining sexual gratification.

change.subject: Part 3 — Amendments consequential on offences in sections 188 and 189
change.quote: "Part 3 — Amendments consequential on offences in sections 188 and 189"
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of Part 3, which contains amendments consequential to the offenses in sections 188 and 189 of the Act.

change.subject: Part 2 of Schedule 15 (specified sexual offences for purposes of section 325)
change.quote: "In Part 2 of Schedule 15 (specified sexual offences for purposes of section 325), after paragraph 149 insert—"
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of a new paragraph after paragraph 149 in Part 2 of Schedule 15, which specifies sexual offenses for the purposes of section 325.

change.subject: section 116 of the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
change.quote: "In section 116 of the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (information about guests at hotels believed to be used for child sexual exploitation), in subsection (8)(c), in the entry that relates to exposure and voyeurism offences in the Sexual Offences Act 2003—"
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of a new entry in section 116 of the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014, which relates to information about guests at hotels believed to be used for child sexual exploitation.

change.subject: Schedule 4 to the Modern Slavery Act 2015
change.quote: "In Schedule 4 to the Modern Slavery Act 2015 (offences to which defence in section 45 does not apply), in paragraph 33 (offences under Sexual Offences Act 2003), after the entry for section 66 insert—"
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of a new entry in Schedule 4 to the Modern Slavery Act 2015, which specifies offenses to which the defense in section 45 does not apply.

change.subject: Part 2 of Schedule 18 to the Sentencing Act 2020
change.quote: "In Part 2 of Schedule 18 to the Sentencing Act 2020 (specified sexual offences for purposes of section 306), in paragraph 38 (offences under Sexual Offences Act 2003), after sub-paragraph (ax) insert—"
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of a new sub-paragraph after sub-paragraph (ax) in Part 2 of Schedule 18 to the Sentencing Act 2020, which specifies sexual offenses for the purposes of section 306.

change.subject: Schedule 9 to the Elections Act 2022
change.quote: "In Schedule 9 to the Elections Act 2022 (offences for purposes of Part 5), after paragraph 47(f) insert—"
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of a new paragraph after paragraph 47(f) in Schedule 9 to the Elections Act 2022, which specifies offenses for the purposes of Part 5.

change.subject: Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Overseas Operations (Service Personnel and Veterans) Act 2021
change.quote: "In Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Overseas Operations (Service Personnel and Veterans) Act 2021 (“excluded offences” for the purposes of section 6 of that Act), omit paragraph 11."
change.summary: The proposed change is the insertion of a new paragraph in Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Overseas Operations (Service Personnel and Veterans) Act 2021, which specifies excluded offenses for the purposes of section 6 of that Act.

change.subject: Schedule 8 (disclosing or threatening to disclose private sexual photographs or films: providers of information society services)
change.quote: "(3) Omit Schedule 8 (disclosing or threatening to disclose private sexual photographs or films: providers of information society services)."
change.summary: The proposed change is the deletion of Schedule 8, which relates to disclosing or threatening to disclose private sexual photographs or films by providers of information society services.

change.subject: section 69 (threats to disclose private sexual photographs and films with intent to cause distress)
change.quote: "(2) Omit section 69 (threats to disclose private sexual photographs and films with intent to cause distress) and the italic heading before it."
change.summary: The proposed change is the deletion of section 69, which relates to threats to disclose private sexual photographs and films with intent to cause distress.

change.subject: Definition of "the relevant day"
change.quote: “the relevant day”, in relation to a pre-existing Part 4B service or to a service which includes a pre-existing Part 4B service, means— (a) the date when section 211 comes into force (repeal of Part 4B of the Communications Act), or (b) if the pre-existing Part 4B service ceases to be a video-sharing platform service before the date mentioned in paragraph (a), the date when that service ceases to be a video-sharing platform service;
change.summary: The bill introduces a definition for "the relevant day" in relation to pre-existing Part 4B services or services that include a pre-existing Part 4B service. It states that the relevant day is either the date when section 211 comes into force (repeal of Part 4B of the Communications Act) or the date when the pre-existing Part 4B service ceases to be a video-sharing platform service.

change.subject: Definition of "safety duties"
change.quote: “safety duties” means the duties mentioned in section 7(2), (4) and (5), except the duties set out in— (a) section 9 (illegal content risk assessments), (b) section 11 (children’s risk assessments), (c) section 14 (assessments related to the adult user empowerment duty set out in section 15(2)), and (d) section 23(2), (9) and (10) (records of assessments);
change.summary: The bill introduces a definition for "safety duties" which refers to the duties mentioned in section 7(2), (4), and (5) of the Act, with exceptions for specific duties listed in sections 9, 11, 14, and 23.

change.subject: Definition of "the transitional period"
change.quote: “the transitional period”, in relation to a pre-existing Part 4B service or to a service which includes a pre-existing Part 4B service, means the period— (a) beginning with the date when this Schedule comes into force, and (b) ending with the relevant day;
change.summary: The bill introduces a definition for "the transitional period" in relation to pre-existing Part 4B services or services that include a pre-existing Part 4B service. It states that the transitional period begins with the date when this Schedule comes into force and ends with the relevant day.

change.subject: Definition of "video-sharing platform service"
change.quote: “video-sharing platform service” has the same meaning as in Part 4B of the Communications Act (see section 368S of that Act).
change.summary: The bill introduces a definition for "video-sharing platform service" which has the same meaning as in Part 4B of the Communications Act.

change.subject: Application of Part 4B of the Communications Act to pre-existing Part 4B services
change.quote: (2) Both this Act and Part 4B of the Communications Act apply in relation to the pre-existing Part 4B service during the transitional period.
change.summary: The bill states that both the Online Safety Bill and Part 4B of the Communications Act apply to pre-existing Part 4B services during the transitional period.

change.subject: Exemptions from duties and requirements for pre-existing Part 4B services
change.summary: The bill states that certain duties and requirements under the Act do not apply during the transitional period in relation to pre-existing Part 4B services. These include safety duties, duties related to fraudulent advertising, user identity verification, reporting CSEA content, terms of service, deceased child users, transparency reports, and information notices for transparency reports.

change.subject: Exemption from OFCOM's powers under Schedule 12
change.quote: (5) OFCOM’s powers under Schedule 12 to this Act (powers of entry, inspection and audit) do not apply during the transitional period in relation to the preexisting Part 4B service.
change.summary: The bill states that OFCOM's powers under Schedule 12 of the Act, which include powers of entry, inspection, and audit, do not apply during the transitional period in relation to pre-existing Part 4B services.

change.subject: Exemption from duties for regulated user-to-user services with regulated provider pornographic content
change.quote: (1) The duties set out in section 82 of this Act do not apply during the transitional period in relation to any regulated provider pornographic content published or displayed on a pre-existing Part 4B service.
change.summary: The bill states that the duties set out in section 82 of the Act do not apply during the transitional period in relation to any regulated provider pornographic content published or displayed on a pre-existing Part 4B service.

change.subject: Application of Part 4B of the Communications Act to regulated user-to-user services with a Part 4B part
change.quote: (1) During the transitional period, Part 4B of the Communications Act applies in relation to a pre-existing Part 4B service within the definition in paragraph (b) of paragraph 1(1).
change.summary: The bill states that during the transitional period, Part 4B of the Communications Act applies in relation to pre-existing Part 4B services within the definition in paragraph (b) of paragraph 1(1).

change.subject: Application of Part 4B of the Communications Act to regulated user-to-user services with a Part 4B part and another user-to-user part
change.quote: (2) During the transitional period— (a) any duty or requirement mentioned in paragraph 3(4) which applies in relation to the regulated service is to be treated as applying only in relation to the rest of the service; (b) the powers mentioned in paragraph 3(5) are to be treated as applying only in relation to the rest of the service.
change.summary: The bill states that during the transitional period, any duty or requirement mentioned in paragraph 3(4) which applies to a regulated user-to-user service with a Part 4B part and another user-to-user part is to be treated as applying only in relation to the rest of the service. Similarly, the powers mentioned in paragraph 3(5) are to be treated as applying only in relation to the rest of the service.

change.subject: Application of Part 4B of the Communications Act to regulated user-to-user services with a Part 4B part and a search engine
change.quote: (2) During the transitional period, no duty or requirement mentioned in paragraph 3(4) applies in relation to the Part 4B part of the service (but that is not to be taken to prevent any other duty or requirement under this Act from applying in relation to the search engine of the service during the transitional period). (3) During the transitional period, the powers mentioned in paragraph 3(5) are to be treated as applying only in relation to the search engine of the service.
change.summary: The bill states that during the transitional period, no duty or requirement mentioned in paragraph 3(4) applies to the Part 4B part of a regulated user-to-user service, but this does not prevent any other duty or requirement under the Act from applying to the search engine of the service. Similarly, the powers mentioned in paragraph 3(5) are to be treated as applying only in relation to the search engine of the service during the transitional period.

change.subject: Application of Part 4B of the Communications Act to regulated user-to-user services with a Part 4B part but no other user-to-user part or search engine
change.quote: (2) The duties, requirements and powers mentioned in paragraph 3(4) and (5) do not apply in relation to the regulated service during the transitional period.
change.summary: The bill states that the duties, requirements, and powers mentioned in paragraph 3(4) and (5) do not apply to a regulated user-to-user service with a Part 4B part but no other user-to-user part or search engine during the transitional period.

change.subject: Assessments of pre-existing Part 4B services or of services which include a pre-existing Part 4B service
change.quote: See Part 3 of Schedule 3 for provision about— (a) the timing of certain assessments of pre-existing Part 4B services, and (b) modifications of Parts 1 and 2 of that Schedule in connection with certain assessments of services which include a pre-existing Part 4B service within the definition in paragraph (b) of paragraph 1(1).
change.summary: The bill refers to Part 3 of Schedule 3 for provisions regarding the timing of certain assessments of pre-existing Part 4B services and modifications of Parts 1 and 2 of that Schedule in connection with certain assessments of services that include a pre-existing Part 4B service within the definition in paragraph (b) of paragraph 1(1).

change.subject: Operation of section 368U of the Communications Act
change.quote: 10 During the transitional period, section 368U of the Communications Act has effect as a requirement to establish and maintain an up to date list of persons providing a video-sharing platform service to which Part 4B applies.
change.summary: The bill states that during the transitional period, section 368U of the Communications Act has the effect of requiring the establishment and maintenance of an up-to-date list of persons providing a video-sharing platform service to which Part 4B applies.

change.subject: Video-sharing platform services which start up, or start up again, during the transitional period
change.quote:
11 Part 4B of the Communications Act does not apply in relation to a videosharing platform service which is first provided on or after the date when this Schedule comes into force.
12 (1) Sub-paragraph (2) applies in relation to a pre-existing Part 4B service if— (a) the service ceases to be a video-sharing platform service on a date within the transitional period, and (b) the service begins again to be a video-sharing platform service on some later date within the transitional period. (2) Part 4B of the Communications Act does not start applying again in relation to the service on the date mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(b).
13 Paragraphs 11 and 12 apply regardless of whether, or when, a provider of a service has notified the appropriate regulatory authority in accordance with section 368V of the Communications Act.
change.summary: The bill states that Part 4B of the Communications Act does not apply to a video-sharing platform service that is first provided on or after the date when this Schedule comes into force. Additionally, if a pre-existing Part 4B service ceases to be a video-sharing platform service within the transitional period and begins again to be a video-sharing platform service on a later date within the transitional period, Part 4B of the Communications Act does not start applying again to the service. These provisions apply regardless of whether or when a provider of a service has notified the appropriate regulatory authority in accordance with section 368V of the Communications Act.

change.subject: Application of Part 6 of this Act: fees
change.summary: The bill introduces a part that makes provision about the application of section 84 (duty to notify OFCOM in relation to the charging of fees), section 85 (payment of fees), and Schedule 10 (additional fees) of the Act in relation to a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service.

change.subject: Application of section 84
change.quote: 16 (1) Sub-paragraph (2) applies in relation to a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service, whether or not the person is the provider of any other regulated service. (2) Section 84, which makes provision about the notification of OFCOM in relation to a charging year, applies to the provider in relation to every charging year, regardless of whether any part, or all, of a charging year falls within the transitional period.
change.summary: The bill states that section 84, which makes provision about the notification of OFCOM in relation to a charging year, applies to a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service in relation to every charging year, regardless of whether any part or all of a charging year falls within the transitional period.

change.subject: Application of section 85: transitional charging year
change.quote:
18 If a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service is an exempt provider, section 85 and Schedule 10 do not apply in relation to the provider in respect of a transitional charging year (see paragraph 23).
19 (1) If a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service is not an exempt provider, section 85 and Schedule 10 apply in relation to the provider in respect of a transitional charging year. (2) But sub-paragraphs (3) and (4) apply in relation to the provider in respect of a transitional charging year if the provider’s notification under section 84 in relation to that charging year has included details of amounts wholly referable to a relevant Part 4B service (as mentioned in paragraph 17(3)). (3) For the purposes of the computation of the provider’s fee under section 85 in respect of the transitional charging year, references in that section to the provider’s qualifying worldwide revenue are to be taken to be references to the provider’s non-Part 4B qualifying worldwide revenue. (4) OFCOM may not require the provider to pay a fee under section 85 in respect of the transitional charging year if the provider’s non-Part 4B qualifying worldwide revenue for the qualifying period that relates to that charging year is less than the threshold figure that has effect for that charging year. (5) The amount of a provider’s “non-Part 4B qualifying worldwide revenue” is the amount that would be the provider’s qualifying worldwide revenue (see section 86) if all amounts wholly referable to a relevant Part 4B service were left out of account.
change.summary: The bill states that if a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service is an exempt provider, section 85 and Schedule 10 do not apply to the provider in respect of a transitional charging year. However, if the person is not an exempt provider, section 85 and Schedule 10 apply to the provider in respect of a transitional charging year. Additionally, if the provider's notification under section 84 in relation to that charging year has included details of amounts wholly referable to a relevant Part 4B service, the computation of the provider's fee under section 85 is based on the provider's non-Part 4B qualifying worldwide revenue. OFCOM may not require the provider to pay a fee if the provider's non-Part 4B qualifying worldwide revenue is less than the threshold figure for that charging year.

change.subject: Application of section 85: non-transitional charging year
change.quote: 20 (1) Sub-paragraph (2) applies in relation to a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service, whether or not the person is the provider of any other regulated service. (2) Section 85 and Schedule 10 apply without modification in relation to the provider in respect of a non-transitional charging year (even if the notification date in relation to such a charging year fell within the transitional period).
change.summary: The bill states that section 85 and Schedule 10 apply without modification to a person who is the provider of a relevant regulated service in respect of a non-transitional charging year, even if the notification date in relation to such a charging year fell within the transitional period.

change.subject: Amounts wholly referable to relevant Part 4B service
change.quote: 21 (1) For the purposes of this Part, OFCOM may produce a statement giving information about the circumstances in which amounts do, or do not, count as being wholly referable to a relevant Part 4B service. (2) If OFCOM produce such a statement, they must publish it (and any revised or replacement statement).
change.summary: The bill states that for the purposes of this Part, OFCOM may produce a statement giving information about the circumstances in which amounts do or do not count as being wholly referable to a relevant Part 4B service. If OFCOM produce such a statement, they must publish it, as well as any revised or replacement statement.

change.subject: Interpretation of this Part
change.quote: 22 In this Part— “non-transitional charging year” means a charging year which is not a transitional charging year; “notification date”, in relation to a charging year, means the latest date by which a notification under section 84 relating to that charging year is required to be given (see section 84(5)); “relevant Part 4B service” means— (a) a regulated user-to-user service described in paragraph 15(a), or (b) a pre-existing Part 4B service included in a regulated user-touser service described in paragraph 15(b).
change.summary: The bill provides definitions for terms used in this Part, including "non-transitional charging year," "notification date," and "relevant Part 4B service."

change.subject: Application of Part 4 of this Schedule after the end of the transitional period
change.quote: 26 In this Part of this Schedule— (a) “the repeal time” means the time when section 211 of this Act comes into force (repeal of Part 4B of the Communications Act); (b) (except in paragraph (a)) references to sections are to sections of the Communications Act.
change.summary: The bill introduces a part that applies after the end of the transitional period. It defines "the repeal time" as the time when section 211 of the Act comes into force, which repeals Part 4B of the Communications Act. It also clarifies that references to sections in this part refer to sections of the Communications Act.

change.subject: OFCOM as appropriate regulatory authority
change.quote: 28 The repeal of section 368T does not affect OFCOM’s powers to act after the repeal time as the appropriate regulatory authority under Part 4B of the Communications Act as it has effect by virtue of this Part of this Schedule.
change.summary: The bill states that the repeal of section 368T does not affect OFCOM's powers to act as the appropriate regulatory authority under Part 4B of the Communications Act after the repeal time.

change.subject: Duties of service providers to co-operate with investigations
change.quote: 29 The repeal of section 368Y(3)(c) (duty to co-operate) does not affect the application of that provision after the repeal time in relation to— (a) an investigation as mentioned in section 368Z10(3)(f) begun before that time, or (b) any demand for information for the purpose mentioned in section 368Z10(3)(i) resulting from such an investigation.
change.summary: The bill states that the repeal of section 368Y(3)(c) (duty to co-operate) does not affect its application after the repeal time in relation to investigations begun before that time or any demand for information resulting from such investigations.

change.subject: Demands for information, and enforcement of such demands
change.quote: 30 (1) The repeal of sections 368Y(3)(b) and 368Z10 (demands for information) does not affect the application of those provisions after the repeal time in a case in which— (a) OFCOM require information after the repeal time for the purposes of an investigation as mentioned in section 368Z10(3)(f), and (b) the investigation was begun before that time. (2) The repeal of sections 368Z2, 368Z4 and 368Z10 does not affect the application of those sections after the repeal time in connection with— (a) a failure to comply with a requirement under section 368Z10 imposed before that time, or (b) a failure to comply with a requirement imposed after that time under section 368Z10 as it has effect in a case mentioned in sub-paragraph (1). (3) In this paragraph— (a) “the purposes of an investigation” include the purposes of any enforcement action or proceedings resulting from an investigation; (b) references to sections 368Z2 and 368Z4 include references to those sections as modified by section 368Z10.
change.summary: The bill states that the repeal of sections 368Y(3)(b) and 368Z10 does not affect their application after the repeal time in cases where OFCOM require information for the purposes of an investigation that was begun before that time. Additionally, the repeal of sections 368Z2, 368Z4, and 368Z10 does not affect their application after the repeal time in connection with failures to comply with requirements imposed before or after that time under section 368Z10. The paragraph also clarifies that references to sections 368Z2 and 368Z4 include references to those sections as modified by section 368Z10.

change.subject: Enforcement notifications, financial penalties etc
change.quote: 31 (1) The repeal of sections 368W and 368Z4 (enforcement of section 368V) does not affect the application of those sections after the repeal time in a case in which OFCOM— (a) made a determination as mentioned in section 368W(1) before that time, or (b) began, before that time, to investigate whether they may have grounds to make such a determination.
change.summary: The bill states that the repeal of sections 368W and 368Z4 does not affect their application after the repeal time in cases where OFCOM made a determination before that time or began an investigation before that time to determine whether they may have grounds to make such a determination.

change.subject: sections 368Z2 and 368Z4
change.quote: The repeal of sections 368Z2 and 368Z4 (enforcement of sections 368Y and 368Z1(6) and (7)) does not affect the application of those sections after the repeal time in a case in which OFCOM—
(a) made a determination as mentioned in section 368Z2(1) before that time, or
(b) began, before that time, to investigate whether they may have grounds to make such a determination.
change.summary: The repeal of sections 368Z2 and 368Z4 does not impact the application of sections 368Y and 368Z1(6) and (7) if OFCOM made a determination or began an investigation before the repeal time.

change.subject: sections 368Z3 and 368Z4
change.quote: The repeal of sections 368Z3 and 368Z4 (enforcement of sections 368Z1(1) and (2)) does not affect the application of those sections after the repeal time in a case in which OFCOM—
(a) made a determination as mentioned in section 368Z3(1) before that time, or
(b) began, before that time, to investigate whether they may have grounds to make such a determination.
change.summary: The repeal of sections 368Z3 and 368Z4 does not impact the application of sections 368Z1(1) and (2) if OFCOM made a determination or began an investigation before the repeal time.

change.subject: section 368Z5
change.quote: The repeal of section 368Z5 (suspension or restriction of service for contraventions or failures) does not affect the application of that section after the repeal time in a case in which OFCOM—
(a) made a determination as mentioned in section 368W(1), 368Z2(1) or 368Z3(1) before that time, or
(b) made such a determination after that time following an investigation begun before that time.
change.summary: The repeal of section 368Z5 does not impact the application of that section if OFCOM made a determination or began an investigation before the repeal time.

change.subject: sections 368Z7 and 368Z8
change.quote: The repeal of sections 368Z7 (directions under sections 368Z5 and 368Z6) and 368Z8 (offence relating to such directions) does not affect the application of those sections after the repeal time in connection with a direction given under section 368Z5 as it has effect by virtue of this paragraph.
change.summary: The repeal of sections 368Z7 and 368Z8 does not impact the application of those sections in connection with a direction given under section 368Z5.
